title: Adverse Events (AET02)
section: Building an AET02 table using the {cards} package
text:
Building an AET02 table using the {cards} package
In this example below we perform different data pre-processing for the different ARDs we want to create. We then generate separate ARDs for the different sections of the AET02 table and then merge them all together.


Show the code
library(cards)

title: Adverse Events (AET02)
text:
Comparing Outputs
Upon comparing the two outputs, it’s evident that both methods yield identical values, enabling their use for Quality Control (QC) purposes.

title: QCing tables with ARDs
text:
QCing rtables
You are likely familiar with the r packages developed by NEST for generating tables and graphs.
A common practice to ensure quality control (QC) of the calculated statistics is double programming - submitting the same data in a different programmatic source to ensure the results align. Historically, these tables are compared to outputs produced by SAS statistical software. Here, we offer an alternative using the Analysis Results Datasets (ARDs). The CDISC Analysis Results Standard aims to facilitate automation, reproducibility, reusability, and traceability of analysis results data (ARD). The {cards} and {cardx} packages can be used to create these analysis datasets.


Recommended QCing workflow
Below we provide an example workflow for QCing tables.

Generate a table using {chevron}


Show the code
library(chevron)

# Create a table using the chevron package 
dmt01 <- chevron::run(dmt01, syn_data)
dmt01


                                       A: Drug X    B: Placebo   C: Combination   All Patients
                                         (N=15)       (N=15)         (N=15)          (N=45)   
  ————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————————
  Age (yr)                                                                                    
    n                                      15           15             15              45     
    Mean (SD)                          31.3 (5.3)   35.1 (9.0)     36.6 (6.4)      34.3 (7.3) 
    Median                                31.0         35.0           35.0            34.0    
    Min - Max                           24 - 40      24 - 57        24 - 49         24 - 57   
  Age Group                                                                                   
    n                                      15           15             15              45     
    <65                                15 (100%)    15 (100%)      15 (100%)       45 (100%)  
  Sex                                                                                         
    n                                      15           15             15              45     
    Male                               3 (20.0%)    7 (46.7%)      5 (33.3%)       15 (33.3%) 
    Female                             12 (80.0%)   8 (53.3%)      10 (66.7%)      30 (66.7%) 
  Ethnicity                                                                                   
    n                                      15           15             15              45     
    HISPANIC OR LATINO                 2 (13.3%)        0              0            2 (4.4%)  
    NOT HISPANIC OR LATINO             13 (86.7%)   15 (100%)      13 (86.7%)      41 (91.1%) 
    NOT REPORTED                           0            0          2 (13.3%)        2 (4.4%)  
  RACE                                                                                        
    n                                      15           15             15              45     
    AMERICAN INDIAN OR ALASKA NATIVE       0        2 (13.3%)       1 (6.7%)        3 (6.7%)  
    ASIAN                              8 (53.3%)    10 (66.7%)     8 (53.3%)       26 (57.8%) 
    BLACK OR AFRICAN AMERICAN          4 (26.7%)     1 (6.7%)      4 (26.7%)       9 (20.0%)  
    WHITE                              3 (20.0%)    2 (13.3%)      2 (13.3%)       7 (15.6%)  




Flatten the table into a data.frame
A rtables based output can be flattened into a data frame using the as_results_df() function from the rtables package. The make_ard argument set to TRUE, will format the data similar to the output generated by the {cards} package.


Show the code
results <- rtables::as_result_df(dmt01, make_ard = TRUE, expand_colnames = TRUE)
results[1:6, -c(1:3)]

Create a comparable ARD
Using the {cards} package, we stack the functions ard_continuous() for the continuous variables and ard_categorical() for categorical variables. The default statistics calculated for each of these data types are included - these can be adapted for bespoke analyses.


Show the code
library(cards)

# build ARDs that calculate relevant statistics for continuous and categorical variables.

ards <- ard_stack(syn_data$adsl, ard_continuous(variables = c(AGE), statistic = ~ continuous_summary_fns(c("N", "mean", "sd", "median", "min", "max"))
  ),
                 ard_categorical(variables = c(AGEGR1, SEX, ETHNIC, RACE)),
                 .by = "ARM",
                 .overall = TRUE)

ards [1:6, -c(1,9:11)]

Visualize statistics comparison
With both data frames containing similar key variables (group_level, variable_label, etc.), statistics can be compared side-by-side by combining the tables.


Show the code
# rework the rtables output to match ----
# rename the group2 to group1, rename stat_name from n to N

reformat <- results |>
  dplyr::select(-c(1:2,7)) |>
  dplyr::rename("group1" = group2, "group1_level" = group2_level, "stat_rtables" = stat) |>
   dplyr::mutate(variable_level = sub("^[^.]*\\.", "", variable_level)) |>
  dplyr::mutate(stat_name = dplyr::recode(stat_name, 
                         "n" = "N",
                         "count" = "n"),
                variable = dplyr::recode(variable, 
                         "AAGE" = "AGE"),
                variable_level = dplyr::recode(variable_level, 
                         "Male" = "M",
                         "Female" = "F")) |>
  dplyr::mutate(variable_level = dplyr::case_when(
    variable_level %in% c("mean_sd", "median", "range", "n") ~ NA_character_,
    TRUE ~ variable_level
  ))

ards2 <- ards |> 
  dplyr::mutate(group1_level = purrr::map_chr(group1_level, 
                                             ~ if (length(.x) > 0) {
                                               as.character(.x[[1]])
                                             } else {
                                               NA_character_
                                             })) |>
    dplyr::mutate(variable_level = purrr::map_chr(variable_level, 
                                             ~ if (length(.x) > 0) {
                                               as.character(.x[[1]])
                                             } else {
                                               NA_character_
                                             })) |>
  dplyr::select(-c(9:11)) |>
  dplyr::mutate(group1 = dplyr::coalesce(group1, "ARM"),
                group1_level = dplyr::coalesce(group1_level, "All Patients"))

# perform a left join

compare <- dplyr::left_join(ards2, reformat, by = c("group1_level","group1", "variable", "variable_level", "stat_name"))
compare[1:20,]

title: Demographics and Baseline Characteristics (DMT01)
section: Building DMT01 statstics using the {cards} package
text:
Building DMT01 statstics using the {cards} package
In this example below, we calculate the same summary statistics usings the {cards} package with the same data set provided by the {chevron} package.


Show the code
library(cards)

# build ARDs that calculate relevant statistics for continuous and categorical variables.

ards <- ard_stack(syn_data$adsl, ard_continuous(variables = c(AGE)),
                 ard_categorical(variables = c(AGEGR1, SEX, ETHNIC, RACE)),
                 .by = "ARM",
                 .overall = TRUE)

title: Demographics and Baseline Characteristics (DMT01)
text:
Comparing Outputs
We can compare the statistics for Mean and SD values for our continuous variable.


Show the code
# Equality in means and sd

# mean_tbl <- results |>
#   dplyr::filter(label_name %in% "Mean (SD)") |>
#   dplyr::select(9:11) |>
#   dplyr::mutate(across(everything(), ~purrr::map_chr(.x, ~paste(.x, collapse = ", "))))
# 
# mean_ard <- ards %>%
#   dplyr::filter(stat_name %in% c("mean", "sd")) %>%
#   dplyr::summarise(
#     "Mean(SD)" = paste(stat[stat_name == "mean"], "(", stat[stat_name == "sd"], ")", sep = ""))
# 
# mean_tbl




Show the code
#mean_ard


We can also compare the statistics related to categorical variables (truncated to make it easier to read).


Show the code
# Equality in n, N and percent

# cat_tbl <- results |>
#   dplyr::filter(avar_name %in% "RACE") |>
#   dplyr::select(c(3,9:11)) |>
#   dplyr::mutate(across(everything(), ~purrr::map_chr(.x, ~paste(.x, collapse = ", "))))
# 
# cat_tbl




Show the code
cat_ard <- ards %>%
  dplyr::filter(variable %in% c("RACE")) |>
  dplyr::filter(stat_name %in% c("n", "N", "p")) 

cat_ard

title: QCing with {cards} and {cardx}
text:
QCing with {cards} and {cardx}
This catalog is meant to demo the use of ARD-centric packages within the Quality Control workflow. Verification of statistics generated with NEST packages (such as: {tern}, {rtables}, {chevron}) can be verified by reproducing the tables using Analysis Results Dataset (ARDs).
